I'm still trying to figure out why I had only a mild case of COVID 19 back in June of 2020. I usually get very sick from anything I'm exposed to. Especially respiratory illnesses. But maybe that's why I didn't get deathly ill from this. I had recently been exposed very regularly to hundreds of people daily and was nearly always sick with colds and flues. Maybe my body was already familiar. I had also just moved from a place where I had severe allergies. The pollen was still on my stuff and I was still reacting, though mildly by then. I was also still taking the steroid nasal spray for allergies to keep my sinuses from going nuts. Plus, I made some very potent herbal antiviral tea that I took round the clock the first few days of the infection.

I suspect that all of the above played a part. I'm really hoping not to be exposed again, though. Now that I've been quarantining for over a year, am no longer exposed to the same allergens, and am no longer taking steroid nasal spray. Fortunately, I still know where my herbs are. But I'm still really hoping not to get sick again.

The few documented 'asymptomatic cases' are problematic. In one case the asymptomatic individual in Germany was later shown to be on medication that suppressed her symptoms. All studies cited on wikipedia for asymptomatic spread are of people with no symptoms (so no signs of any disease) but only 'confirmed' as 'infected' by a positive PCR.
Now in most cases we don't know what cycle threshold (Ct-value) these particular tests used, but we know from eg. Rita Jafaar et al, that (even for covid) cycle values above 25 are wildly inaccurate, as they basically only amplify background noise. Above 35 Ct and only <3% of positive tests later show positive in culture (which suggests a false positive rate of >97%).
A PCR also only detects RNA fragments, not full viruses, so it can be positive from the remains of a virus that has already been destroyed by the immune system, or from fragments that never were a virus or infectious in the first place. PCR can in no way tell you if someone is sick or infectous.
Asymptomatic spread also doesn't make sense biologically. If there is not enough virus in the body for cells to show any reaction, eg. fever (fighting the infection) then how should there be enough virus to spread around to other people.
And just as expected, a large study in China in September 2020 (Shiyi Cao et al, published in nature) has found "There were no positive tests amongst 1,174 close contacts of asymptomatic cases."
We need to face the reality, that there are no 'asymptomatic cases'. They are not 'cases' since they don't show any signs of a disease ('asymptomatic'). Those people are just healthy.
